title: Much ado about nothing
review:
Let me begin explaining this:

  • ZODIAC has duration of 160 minutes or 2 hours and 40 minutes. - Is about the investigation of a serial killer that can only be demonstrated three killings even when he claims 13 or more. - The killer was never caught - The movie is based on real events


At almost three hours ZODIAC could have been a decent four night's miniseries in any network channel. The three killings are strong but not really gory. It does not have "A" list actors even when the acting is excellent.

Even if you do not know the story (as it was my case) after the first half, there not much to sustain any interest. All you get are continuous dialogs, a little humor and more dialogs.

Robert Downey Jr character is the only one interesting (but partially developed). No other really deserves real interest or rooting for.

In brief; I am sure there are better ways to spend almost three hours of your life.

title: One word: whoa!
review:
I was a class-room clown, in grammar school, when most of the events, in this highly suspenseful true story, took place. So, all I knew about the Zodiac Killer, before getting into see this movie, was that he had never officially been caught.

And, now I know why.

The first-third of the movie is undeniably the creepiest, as the actual murders occur, and you hear voiced over recordings of the killer anonymously phoning the cops to virtually brag about it!

That's also where you're introduced to Robert Downey, Jr. as a cynical, semi-alcoholic, and apparently gay crime reporter; Jake Gyllenhaal as an editorial cartoonist with an obsessive-compulsive penchant for puzzles and cryptographs; and Mark Ruffalo as the SFPD detective who ultimately--and unfairly--bears the lion's share of responsibility for never bringing in the killer.

How the murders, and the mocking letters that gradually outnumber them, affect each of the above-mentioned characters is what makes the final third of the movie less (inevitably) boring than the middle third. Gyllenhaal, especially, makes you want to scream out loud, at the movie screen: "Get a life, you idiot! You're wife is right!"

Some of you are probably asking yourselves, right now, why I don't give this a perfect ten, if I liked it so much. Simple: the semi-fictionalized murder scene at the lake. The disclaimer at the start of the film said that the whole thing was based on actual case files. But, if neither the man nor the woman--so brutally stabbed at the lake--survived, how did Robert Graysmith get that part about the Zodiac Killer claiming to have escaped from a prison in Montana?

title: Pleasantly Surprised
review:
Zodiac is as much a horror film as Barney's Great Adventure is a documentary. Most of the footage in the ads takes place in the first half-hour of the movie, and is occasionally touched upon later throughout. Now, all that said, those few murder scenes are not afraid to show the violence, so it's still not something for children to watch.

The rest of the movie focuses on cartoonist Robert Graysmith (Jake Gyllenhaal), his colleague Paul Avery (Robert Downey Jr.), and several detective agencies as they attempt to track down the infamous Zodiac killer.

The movie takes place across a span of about 20 or so years, jumping forward as new evidence emerges. It's based quite faithfully on the real Zodiac killings and the investigations that followed. The film is actually based on the book written by the real Robert Graysmith.

The acting throughout the film is very impressive, especially on the part of Gyllenhaal, who manages to convincingly depict Graysmith's plunge from a simple cartoonist, to an obsessive man who begins to neglect his own family in his desperate search for the identity of the Zodiac. Gyllenhaal wasn't the greatest actor in the film however, my personal favorite was that of Robert Downey Jr., who plays Paul Avery. Avery is the polar opposite of Graysmith, instead of plunging deeper and deeper into the Zodiac case, he simply drinks himself into oblivion. Downey Jr. is very animated throughout his performance, and is very reminiscent of his role as Jim Barris in 2006's A Scanner Darkly. One of my only complaints about the movie is that Downey's character is criminally underused. His talents as an actor far surpass the screen time he receives in this movie.

One complaint many people seem to have with Zodiac is that it's too long. Clocking in at about 2 and a half hours, it's no slouch in the length department. It's a very compelling 2 and a half hours though, and I had no problem sitting there and watching this case unfold. I encourage those who see it to do so without any prior research on the Zodiac. The less you know about what really happened, the more you'll enjoy this movie. That's not to say it's inaccurate, but I walked in knowing several things about the Zodiac's murders, and felt it detracted a little from the overall experience. Nothing to write home about of course, but there's nonetheless more enjoyment to be had when you don't know how the story will play out.

I was particularly interested in seeing how the movie would end. It's no secret that the Zodiac case was never officially solved. They did a very good job with it though, they leave with satisfying closure without giving any definitive answers. One could make a very compelling argument that the final scene is one of the best in the film. Graysmith walks up to the man he believes is the Zodiac. The man looks at Graysmith, smiles, and says "Can I help you?". Graysmith simply replies "No...No it's alright...", but continues to stare at him. The man's smile fades, suggesting that he might know what's going on, but again no answers are given. The camera moves to Graysmith once again, watches him for a moment, and the movie closes.

Overall, Zodiac was a very pleasant surprise, and I would encourage anyone remotely interested in a well-crafted Crime Drama to take a look. Ignore the ads, ignore the media hype. Zodiac is a much better film than it's given credit for.

title: Closure Please?
review:
This CONTAINS SPOILERS

I sat there for 2 hours waiting for the capture of the Zodiac, well I guess they thought that sticking to the true story of the Zodiac, being that he was actually never caught, was better than making a good film. So what to do?, What to do?, how to end a true story with no real ending? I say improvisation would have been fun, but they decided to go with the old text ending. How much fun that was, I sat there for five mins reading text that was attempting to conclude this poor excuse for a murder mystery and at then end of this essay on screen he ends up dies a natural death UN-CAPTURED. This just may be the most boring film ever recreated( and who created the first one, must have been an idiot), DO NOT WATCH THIS IF YOUR YOUNG (13-25) but if your are old and boring then by all means see this film.

title: Best movie of 2007 at the earliest. David Fincher's masterpiece of tense mystery suspense drama
review:
Prefacing the review, here is an anecdote of David Fincher's complaint about his experience working on the film set of Alien 3: "There's no one who hated Alien3 more than I did... I got hired for a personal vision and was railroaded into something else. I had never been devalued or lied to or treated so badly. I wasn't used to adults lying to me. I didn't read a script for a year and a half after that. I thought I'd rather die of colon cancer than do another movie." (Excerpt from "The Allure of Decay" by Amy Taubin Sight and Sound, January 1996)

16 years later, David had a similar battle with the studio trying to keep the film running at the uncompromised theatrical cut length he felt would be right. The previous cut ran 3 hours and ten minutes. And the result is the studio's poor treatment of the film "Zodiac" with lackluster marketing (including deceptive trailer that sent the ignorant young people to the movies expecting a blood-splashing slasher horror-thriller, much to their chagrin and disgust) and withdrawn Oscar campaign.

In spite of this, David have finally made a masterpiece that is so unique and completely otherworldly that it's a mind-bendingly absorbing movie-going experience.

I didn't like Fincher's other films, including the nauseatingly disturbing Seven (I can never forget how vitriol my father was in expressing his loathing of the movie and warned me not to see it because he said it made him feel genuinely ill when I was a teenager; I concurred with him although the film had its merits despite black ending) and self-consciously smug & perversely indulgent Fight Club. The Game was meant to be seen only once. Panic Room didn't hold up well -- his weakest film so far, with a trademark lousy ending. Alien 3 is the most fascinating movie in the Alien franchise for its bizarre, unconventional, depressingly pessimistic storytelling and troubled production that is eventually redeemed by the assembly cut edition. Alien 3 theatrical cut opened my eyes to David Fincher as the truly promising new director (despite the studio's butchery in editing room) whose demonstrable proof of his prodigious film-making talent was mind-blowing, to say the least.

This time Mr. Fincher tried his hand at directing a true crime drama and he have proved himself to be an absolutely adept and astonishingly talented filmmaker with the eyes for the mood and creepily disturbing atmosphere in masterful cinematography utilizing drab brown-orange-black color hues to full effect and ears for the music and sound effects that get under the unsuspecting viewers' skin to scare the crap out of them.

I will not say a word about the plot, because the less the viewer know when he/she go in, the better. But it is about facing the true banality of evil from the viewer's perspective which have a strange effect on the viewer that make it a weirdly tense, intoxicatedly gripping and at times frighteningly creepy experience. This is why we go to the movies to experience the riveting drama and emotions, folks.

If the viewer do not expect a flashy movie and can actually appreciate the merits of an intricate murder mystery drama heavy on dialogues as the pivot of suspense & character development (anyone who enjoyed taut suspense thrillers i.e. The Day of the Jackal, All the President's Men and The Insider), all the better. This is not a typical movie that have the camera shots flying all over with rapid cuts and loud music effects. Quite the contrary despite the semi-misleading movie trailer.

The actual movie subliminally request the viewers to pay attention and have some patience -- it's not slow-moving with filler moments, but the very essence of the story politely demand the viewers to surrender their selfish pretension upon start of the movie's beginning and let the vision roll over them in the course of over two hours and a half.

I'm taken aback that given Mr. Fincher's background in music video directing, he's restrained in the pretentiously cool visual effects and power cut flashes that other film directors of similar background (and yes, Tony Scott included) love to throw at the audience. Instead, Fincher let the story unfold itself through mood, dialogue, linear plot and editing, stellar acting by the leads & supports and subtlety of extraordinary cinematography and stunning visual effects.

The story is so dense I had to watch the movie two times within two days to absorb. It was unbelievably (although only a few slow spots that are thankfully brief) riveting for its storytelling power coupled with top-notch production values, which obviously cost high sums of money.

Zodiac is tragically under-appreciated as a commercial flop due to the majority of the audience's disdain out of short-attention-span impatience, dissatisfaction and ignorance. Almost every great film suffer audience lashing (including 2001: A Space Odyssey -- recollect Rock Hudson's grumble as he walks out on the aisle at the premiere screening "Will someone tell me what the hell this is about?!?").

Mark my word, Zodiac will stand the test of time as viewer appreciation grow and it will be seen as a great movie. The same screening where I saw this film twice was nearly empty, with only a middle-aged couple and an unaccompanied elderly lady in her 70's the first time, and elderly couple in their 70's or 80's (they look really old) the second time. All of them liked the film.

I am only a 28 years old man. I felt humbled by their patient & enjoyable presence -- Zodiac the movie receiving the respect through appreciation for the conveyance of top quality film art as entertainment that also rivet & educate.

Major kudos to the visual effects artists for the jaw-dropping shots of the overhead camera shot of a yellow taxi cruising through the streets and the meticulously laid time-lapse construction of Transamerica tower.

**** out of four

title: Just a waste of time
review: Don't watch. Just a waste of time. Very disappointed

title: Engrossing film. Kodos to Fincher!
review: This film is long at over 2 hours (nearly 2.5) but I was not bored at all during this very engrossing film. It was also kind of gritty. You got a sense of the realism of it all. It's like "Ya, I'm watching a real movie." It just feels like a true story. It starts off with some violence that is excellently portrayed. It really sucks you in. This jumps you straight into the hunt for the Zodiac character, which is where you'll meet the cast of newsies and some cops on the case. God I love Robert Downey. God bless the dude for hanging in there with his excellent career. They guy is good. So were Jake Gyllenhaal and Mark Ruffalo. OK so the plot thickens as we see what this Zodiac can do and how he operates. There are a few scenes that can get you squirming in your seat, like at the park but it only solidifies your desire to see that this peace of work gets what's comin to him. As you move through some time lines, quite a lot of time actually, you start to think that this guy may never get caught. It's freakin depressing. You'll feel for the Robert Graysmith character and Inspector David Toschi, especially Graysmith (Jake Gyllenhaal ) who at times is in a near frenzy to bring this guy to justice, nearly single-handedly. I'd love to say more but this is the type of movie that it seems like anything you say will give away too much. I can tell you its long, excellently made, acted and directed. Gritty and engrossing describe it best I think.

title: Fincher matured: Zodiac
review: One of the more interesting things about Zodiac is that it's laid back. This is a story that spans 20 years, with numerous reporters and investigators involved as well as a slew of suspects. You'd expect it to be complicated, probably overly so. Yet director Fincher let's the story flow simply. The perspective is the reporters, the detectives, and the victims. Fincher tells the movie like Graysmith wrote the book: a presentation of facts and observations. This lets the audience interact with the movie. As Robert Graysmith (Gylenhaal) is piecing the case together, so are we until the next revelation of factual evidence (which you will see was bare, but the amount of circumstantial evidence against a certain suspect was a mountain high). As most people know, the Zodiac was never caught. A big question in peoples' minds before seeing this movie is, "is there a resolve?" The movie provides enough brain food for you to come to your own conclusions and that's what makes it such a good watch.

title: One of David Fincher's better movies
review: For me, it isn't his best, but it really is an impressive film. The best thing about Zodiac is its atmosphere, it is really quite chilling and affecting. Equally impressive is the story, it is a very intriguing one and told very cleverly as it probes the limits of knowledge and evidence with startling power. The script is very well written and really makes you think. And it isn't a David Fincher movie without great visuals and indeed Zodiac has that. The cinematography is really quite skillful and the scenery, locations and lighting match the brooding atmosphere wonderfully. Fincher also does a superb directing, in fact his direction is a primary factor in what makes Zodiac one of his better movies. This serial killer is also quite different, and this is in a good way. Fincher allows the brutality of the murders to take second place to how the investigation takes its toll on the protagonists, and I for one found that quite refreshing. The acting is equally good, Jake Gyllenhaal can be bland sometimes, but he has given some good performances too and his performance here is one of them. Mark Ruffalo is even better, and Robert Downey Jnr even more so. So overall, different but refreshing, clever and well made film and one of Fincher's better movies. 9/10 Bethany Cox

title: Brilliant film-making. CANNOT believe they didn't recognize this at the Oscars!!
review:
David Fincher, in my opinion is a movie-making genius. He hasn't made, what one would call, a LOT of movies, but each and every one he has made has stood out. I've seen all his full-length features to date. From Se7en to Fight Club. Now, I know many people will disagree with what I'm saying, but, in my opinion, Zodiac is his best. And for more reasons than one, if I made a list of my Top 20 Hollywood movies, Zodiac would be one of them.

In the late 1960's through till the late 1970's a notorious serial killer who called himself The Zodiac haunted the San Francisco Bay Area. It is not known exactly how many murders he committed. For the purpose of publicity, he used to mail letters and zodiac codes to famous newspapers in the city giving them information which only he could know, taunting the Police to carry out a mass investigation. Till date, the case remains one of the greatest unsolved crimes of San Francisco. The movie is based on actual case files, and adapted from Robert Graysmith's Zodiac account books.

I saw Zodiac on a sultry afternoon, in the dark confines of my room. It is a two hour thirty seven minute movie. It felt no more than ninety minutes. By now, those who have read my takes on movies will know that I hold the background music as, perhaps, the most important factor in getting the viewers into the basic feel of the movie. Zodiac has got a blend of 60's Jazz, Pop and Rock music. Even the closing credits have got music enough to make you remain seated and hear it out. It has a gripping background score. The film starts, and ends, with the same song. The song : Hurdy Gurdy Man. It is stylized, almost scary, along with a nod-ya-head vibe to it.

The movie has an ensemble cast. With the likes of Jake Gyllenhaal, Robert Downey Jr., Mark Ruffalo, and Brian Cox, the acting is stellar. Ruffalo's portrayal of Inspector David Toschi is the pick of the lot. Gyllenhaal, playing the role of Robert Graysmith, a cartoonist for the San Francisco Chronicle whose obsession with The Zodiac leads to the most striking amount of evidence in the case, carries on the express that he started with Brokeback Mountain. I have never seen Chloe Sevigny's other avatar, but her coldness shines in every scene we see her. The whole 1960's/70's setting merely adds to the excellent screenplay. The film has a black imagery. The only clear amount of brightness we get is in the first five minutes, coming from a flashlight.

The dialogue is gripping. The delivery is perfect. The screenplay, sublime. Everything is just right. The cinematography, the setting, the direction. It just fits right in. There was not a moment during its length that I looked at my watch or thought that it was long. It is edge of the seat stuff. The movie is perfect. I didn't know much about the Zodiac killings till I saw this movie. It interested me enough to spend a day reading whatever I could find on the net. When a movie gets you to do that, it says something. For all that its worth, I cannot find a single reason why this movie was overlooked at the Oscars. If this isn't Oscar material, I'm not sure what is.

By the time the movie ended, Zodiac left me stranded with a million random thoughts jumping in my head. It's a thriller of amazing proportions. It just gets you. Whether it is Downey Jr's stylized portrayal of an engaged reporter, shifting to a drunkard who doesn't really give a damn, or the very voice of the Zodiac over the phone. The opening sequence, 5 minutes long, only sets you up for a treat of a movie. This is vintage cinema.

Brilliant. Absolutely brilliant. Watch out for the opening sequence. It rocked me to my core. Highly recommended to anyone who loves watching movies. Straight 10!

title: The fruits of obsession
review:
Do you want to see a film about a serial killer with no solid conclusion? David Fincher does, so he made it. That is a little unfair, but essentially that is the genesis of this film.

David Fincher was a young boy in San Francisco when the Zodiac killer started to strike. He can distinctly recall the little articles of fear that floated throughout the city and when he wasn't allowed to go on the school bus because his mother was too afraid for his safety. It is something that Fincher has, to an extent, obsessed about. How apt then that this film should be such a detailed and effective study of obsession.

Jake Gyllenhaal's Robert Graysmith is an awkward character, a good man but unusual. However, when his paper, the San Francisco Chronicle, receives teasing ciphers from the Zodiac killer, he, an outsider in the paper's hierarchy, becomes more and more interested and more and more obsessed. He descends from a man who likes solving crossword puzzles to a man utterly determined to solve one of the most complex and notorious unsolved crimes in US history. It is utterly compelling to watch.

Fincher evokes the period of the late sixties and early seventies with ease. The film is perfectly designed and at many points ingeniously shot. He creates tension brilliantly. The fear that soaks into the city and the characters is almost tangible and the sheer horror of the few murders that are shown serves to enhance this. Some sequences are genuinely terrifying, and yet nothing happens in them. Examples like this show Fincher to be a master.

He is supported in his efforts by an intelligent script delivered by a pitch perfect cast. James Vanderbilt's screenplay is responsible. It ends with a bit of speculation but all of the events that are crucial to the case happened and you get the sense that this is a fair representation. He provides detailed characters that the talented performers devour with ease. Mark Ruffalo delivers a truly fine performance. Robert Downey Jnr. does one of his usual mumbling but somehow gripping supporting roles (gripping mainly because you're straining to her what he's saying). However, Jake Gyllenhaal is, once again, the standout. He really has developed into one of the world's finest actors and has a rich and varied career ahead of him.

This is one of the finest thrillers of 2007, a really interesting, entertaining and gripping work. It outshines the slightly surreal nature of "Fight Club" and is a masterclass in film-making from one of contemporary cinema's often unappreciated greats. But this is more than just a simple thriller. It is an exploration of one of humanity's most perplexing traits: obsession. And who better to do it than an obsessive.

title: Is this really worth of the Top 250?
review:
I saw this film recently without seeing any critical reviews or any vibe on here. Bearing in mind some of Fincher's previous work I was a bit disappointed with the film. I was somewhat surprised therefore to see it sitting proudly in the Top 250.

The film follows the real life case of the serial killer labelled Zodiac who terrorised the San Fancisco area with a series of murders in the age of flower power. The main focus on the film is the investigation of the murders and I found the thick end of 3 hours a bit on the long side. Anyway it's clearly the case that lots of people enjoyed the film, so you'll need to check it out yourselves. I'll be watching it again when it's on TV to see if there's more to the film than I saw on my first viewing.

title: Started well.. Deteriorated thereafter
review:
I've got to say, when I came to look at the reviews after having watched 'Zodiac' tonight, I was very surprised to see so many positive reviews. Having watched it with a few friends tonight, I was very disappointed. The film started off very promising, with some rather brutal scenes filmed intimately for maximum impact - had me squirming in my seat and I was set for an hour or so's worth of engaging cinema. But the film deteriorated steadily from that point onwards, having me fidgeting in my seat until I was too lethargic to move. The pace appeared to disappear from about 1 hour in and never returned from that point onwards. I appreciate this is a movie recording over 20 years worth of actual events, but at some point the director must use some 'artistic license' to introduce some entertainment...

Robert Downey Jnr. was fantastic portraying a drunkard spiralling towards his own self-destruction...perfect casting from that point of view...

All in all, a little to serious and slow-moving for my liking... but hey, each to their own

title: A Fascinating Portrait of a Mystery by the Master of Loom
review:
Zodiac reviewed by Samuel Osborn

Consider the complications involved in making Zodiac. Fact: the Zodiac killer was never caught. Fact: Robert Graysmith, the main character, survived to write the books the film is based upon and is still alive today. These two very relevant, very essential facts are widely known. So how does a filmmaker go about making a thriller where any suspense surrounding the hero is moot, and where the audience already knows the ending? These aren't spoilers, they're circumstances. They force Zodiac into uncultivated territory, and it makes for the most beguiling mystery sincewell, since the last time David Fincher made a film about serial killers (Se7en).

What first must be realized, I suppose, is that Zodiac is probably not what audiences expect. The film was meant for an Oscar slating. Planned for November 2006 release, complications in post-production and the final cut pushed it out to its present low-key March release (exact details are sketchy). Typical March fare is stuff like Ghost Rider and 300 (which, by the way, is a glorious piece of work); pulpy films without the earning power for a more lucrative summer release. What this all means for Zodiac is that audiences walk in expecting a lot of blood, a lot of violence, and a lot of hair-tearing insanity from the type of serial killer that gets a March release. Zodiac isn't that film. This isn't even what David Fincher, veteran of such cult favorites as Fight Club and Panic Room, is known for putting out. Zodiac is long (160 minutes), obsessed with tiny evidential details, and the humble owner of only three death sequences, all of which occur within the first hour. The film takes a very sober look at a serial killer, reminding us maybe of Silence of the Lambs. But let's not get too carried away. It is only March, after all.

The film begins with the grim, giddy excitement of discovering an emerging serial murderer. Jake Gyllenhaal plays Robert Graysmith, a straight-laced cartoonist at the San Francisco Chronicle, one of the three Bay Area publications that, beginning in October of 1969, Zodiac sent his infamous letters to. Paul Avery, a drunken, goofily arrogant journalist played by Robert Downey Jr., covers the murders, putting himself in the way of Inspector Bill Armstrong (Anthony Edwards) and Inspector David Toschi (Mark Ruffalo), the detectives assigned to the case. After the initial popular craze of the Zodiac plays its course, Mr. Fincher locks the story on the Inspectors' investigation. When they run out of threads and put the case reluctantly down, Mr. Graysmith picks it up, volunteering his own bizarre obsession with the killer.

Where Graysmith was meticulous with his evidence in the book, it seems Fincher here was meticulous with every element of this picture. There have been reports of him demanding, in true Kubrick style, seventy or more takes from his actors. The results, despite some disgruntled remarks from Gyllenhaal, are stunning performances from all the main players. Ruffalo, Downey Jr., Gyllenhaal, and Chloe Sevigny as Graysmith's second wife all put up careful, driven performances.

Mr. Graysmith's book, also enigmatically titled Zodiac, is essentially a documentation of case files. It's dry and painstakingly thorough (read: a back-of-your-seat, have-to-put-down thriller). And when rumors trickled out that Fincher was going to ridiculous lengths to achieve the same level of accuracymurder sequences are supposedly accurate up to the centimeter in terms of the choreographyI admit to having some worries over the same true crime boredom of the book's adaptation.

But thankfully, Screenwriter James Vanderbilt has done a laudable job. As much as Zodiac is about the investigation, it's also about the lives of those obligated and those willing to bring the killer's identity to light. Because of this the film doesn't move like most mystery thrillers do; its pacing is steady and quietly propulsive, allowing the true evidence and mesmerizing reality of the case turn the motor. The thrills swing like mean whispers and arise from the actions of its ultra-dimensional characters.

And although Fincher might have chosen a slower, more thoughtful script, he approaches the text with the same urban Gothic loom he's famous for. The camera work tickles the dark, provocative underbelly of San Francisco at that time period, dynamically gliding through black and blue shadows and warm lamplight glow. His portrait of a mystery is wide and solemn and ponderous, but never to be mistaken with boring. Its barbs are sharp and cruelly disturbing at times. Like in The Game, Fight Club, and Se7en before it, Zodiac displays Fincher's enthrallment in our natural obsession with human destruction, be it mental or physical. And as usual, his dissection of this ironic fascination is utterly satisfying.

Samuel Osborn

title: A thriller that really makes you think.
review: The late 60's really were turbulent times, first with Charles Mansion, and a killer that calls himself Zodiac. He would kill people and make announcements to the police about it, and he would also write letters of mystery. But the story itself is not just a suspenseful thriller, it is also a story about the people investigating, and how it begins to take it's toll on all of them has the years pass by. Newspaper cartoonist Robert Graysmith(Jake Gyllenhaal) and reporter Paul Avery(Robert Downey Jr) try to uncover the clues of the killer, has two homicide detectives(Mark Ruffalo and Anthony Edwards). But do they ever find the Zodiac killer, I'm not gonna tell you,you'll half to see the movie to find out. This was a great movie, and a great cast that gives great performances.

title: Great Film!
review:
I have to start this review by saying if you want a slasher flick, this isn't it. This is more a light dramatization of the events surrounding the Zodiac slayings, and is not intended to satisfy your splatter needs. Additionally (and surprisingly) a survivor of a Zodiac attack, when interviewed on CNN live, proclaimed this movie to be "chillingly accurate" in its depiction of his encounter with the Zodiac.

With a real documentary-like feel, in an entertaining fashion, this story unfolds in a timely manner, and really delivers. As a docu-drama, it is surprisingly entertaining. If forensics, criminal histories, journalistic intrigues, or serial killers are of an interest to you, this movie will hold you in thrall.

I thoroughly enjoyed this work, and can't wait to include it into my DVD collection.

It rates an 8.6/10 from...

the Fiend :.

title: Not for the ADD generation.
review:
Warning: This film is flawed.

That said, I thoroughly enjoyed Zodiac. Robert Downey Jr. was the stand-out of the cast, but other than Gyllenhall (who should have just quit after 'Donnie Darko') the cast as a whole was fine.

As has been said, 'Seven' is better, but we've all seen that flick about 400 times, right? Fincher was on point and his refusal to pick one character as the lead is a Fincher trade-mark (see: Seven, Fight Club).

Fincher succeeds in holding the (mature) audiences attention and manipulating our emotions whether through our frustration as suspects (whom we are convinced are the Zodiac) slip through our fingers, or through our fear as the killer(s) closes in on his prey.

Some will argue that this movie was 'too long', but this complaint will mainly come from the 'ADD generation' raised on music videos.

The soundtrack was great and very moody. Donovan's 'Hurdy-Gurdy Man' being the creepy stand-out.

All-in-all this movie delivers and is the best thing in theatres right now. If you get bored easily, just go watch '300' instead.

title: Zodiac Film Review
review:
People expecting to see another Seven will be disappointed, but that does not mean in any way that David Finchers newest thriller is not a success. Preoccupied with the bureaucracy's and failures of communication Zodiac deals not with the mind of the killer himself, nor the characters pursuing him, but instead focuses on the procedural department of this three decade spanning investigation. Instead of consuming their lives with the serial killer himself, the three main pursuers are engulfed in a battle with paper work and attempted county to county cooperation. What the film deals with is not the nail biting, stomach churning murders that Seven drew upon so well, but the actual procedures the Zodiac took in his killings. Unfortunately it seems Fincher chose to direct this epic crime drama of over two and a half hours without any of his visual style. With the exception of a handful of memorable shots including a shot of a letter inside a mail box being walked through a building until it reaches its receiver, and a brilliantly engaging shot that follows a taxi cab from a helicopter view, Zodiac seems very lackluster especially considering this is coming from the man who brought us the visually stunning Fight Club.

Despite this visual setback, Zodiac never feels boring or contrived, and I cannot be sure yet if this was because of my interest in the case itself or due to Fincher's smooth direction. Either way the film must be praised for telling a story with no resolution and never getting lost in its own path. Trying to tell a story like this, of an unsolved murder case, is a perceptive look into the minds of the obsessed. It exemplifies how one man can psychologically blind people from the outside world concentrating all attention on himself. Again, many people looking for the suspense and blood shed they enjoyed in Se7en will be introduced to a new form of torture, which in this case is psychological.

Jake Gyllenhaal plays Graysmith, a cartoon artist who becomes obsessed with the Zodiac case during his employment at the San Fransisco Chronicle. Gyllenhaal plays more of a supporting role in this, even though the trailers would like us to think otherwise. Mark Ruffallo, playing a detective out of Vallero county takes most of the screen time with his purposely low key voice, which seems to distract more than sooth as its striving intentions might want us to believe. Zodiac is more of collective cast adding Chloe Sevigny, Graysmith's wife dealing with his obsession and Robert Downey Jr. playing Paul Avery a reporter whose addiction to cocaine and alcohol must be a throwback to the actor himself. Obviously this powerful cast helps keep this film together as it follows its three act structure, making each character more important as one act ends and another begins. The first act deals with the media and their reactions to what appeared as legitimate threats. THe second act pushes into a bout with several detectives all dealing with same problem of miscommunication. And the third act introduces us to Graysmith's ongoing obsession with the unsolved murder mystery.

Audiences falling in line for Zodiac expecting another Se7en are likely to be bored and disappointed overall. This movie is low-key and tasteful, avoiding any embellishments, and sticking to the facts of this case. Zodiac is not trying to scare people or even pull them into the world of a serial killer the way Se7en did so well. Instead this is a film about procedural's and communication, which might be a very distracting set of issues for someone to deal with, when going into a supposed thriller.

title: Cinema doing what it does best
review:
Cinema is at its strongest when it transports you to another time and place. Watching Zodiac, I felt like I was in San Francisco in the 1960s/70s/80s/90s. I felt the excitement of a city gripped in terror at a faceless yet enigmatic killer and I felt like I was in the clutches of the obsession that devoured 4 men.

A lot of criticism of this film has been leveled at the fact that it is a 2 1/2 hour film without resolution. For a start, I could have sat through 6 hours of police work on this case and not be bored. And relating to that, that the case is never solved (which, admittedly, I was worried about when I first heard about it), is the most perfect and ONLY way this film could and should be ended. It is not like Deadwood Season 3 ***POSSIBLE 'DEADWOOD' SPOILERS*** where I screamed at the TV for not betraying history and having Swearingen BEAT THE LIVING HELL FROM HEARST, if history was changed in this case it would have weakened the movie, as at its heart it is a tale of obsession and having the case unresolved serves only to underline this theme.

Another concern some people seem to have with this film is that Zodiac is, as a serial killer, an "underachiever", having only 5 confirmed kills. The film only shows 3 of these murders and while for some, murders may equate to quality (Zodiac being therefore 3/7 of the film that Se7en is) the point is that Zodiac, as a villain who effectively uses the media to publicize himself, is a different kind of serial killer, a master of self-promotion and a bigger scalp for those who hunt him. The lack of murders in no way hurts the film - if anything it makes the killer a more thrilling quarry.

The film is perfectly-paced and immaculately production-designed and for anyone wanting an absorbing chase (in the plodding, police-work sense) and a world you never have need to doubt is exactly the time and place it professes to be, Zodiac is the film for you.

title: Four Men, One Obsession: Who is the Zodiac?
review:
On December 20th, 1968, Darlene Ferrin and Mike Mageau are shot. Darlene dies and Mike lives. Seven months later, the San Francisco Chronicle receives a letter in which the writer claims he is Darlene's killer and intends to kill again. This letter would not only terrify the public, but would start an obsession for four men. This obsession would ruin marriages and careers. For the next two decades, these four men were fixated on one question, one that would never be completely answered, a question that may, within itself, be just as dangerous as finding the answer: Who is the Zodiac? Zodiac is a superb film that is as realistic and authentic as a film based on actual events film can be. It is filled with characters who can only be inspired by actual people. The film boasts an excellent cast, with every actor contributing scintillating performances. Robert Downey, Jr., is charismatic and quirky as Paul Avery, bringing this character to life, as the audience witnesses his descent from a funny and brilliant ace reporter to a practically unemployable alcoholic. Anthony Edwards is pensive and understated as the cop who cannot handle the pressure of an unsolved case. Mark Ruffalo's Detective Dave Toschi is a determined and streetwise cop whose frustration almost consumes him, as each lead produces insufficient evidence to charge a suspect. Finally, Jake Gyllenhaal's Robert Graysmith is funny and heartwarming as the cartoonist-turned-amateur-sleuth, who comes the closest to solving the crime.

The director, David Fincher, is masterful at bringing the dark and macabre to the screen and he does not disappoint with Zodiac. The attacks are not as dark or elaborate as those seen in his previous film, Se7en, yet the director still manages to portray each murder as cold, callous, and shocking. The story is brilliantly told in chronological order, starting with the first victims. We see what starts off as a routine murder investigation grow out of control, as two detectives and two reporters become consumed by the hunt for the Zodiac murderer. These four stories are presented in a way that seems believable and genuine. Their obsession seems to leap off the screen and touch its audience. As the film progresses, the viewer also becomes obsessed with the pursuit of the killer. However, this pursuit is not going to end with Harry Callahan shooting the killer dead. There is no neat Hollywood ending to this film; it will not answer all of your questions. In fact, you will find yourself asking that same question  Who is the Zodiac? The DVD extras contain the usual mix of trailers, but it also contains a "featurette" on the making of the movie. Fincher fans will love this. If you are not convinced that Fincher strived to create a film that was both authentic and unbiased, you will be after watching this insight into his process. The Zodiac DVD is available for purchase on September 24th.

title: You might as well watch a documentary
review:
I'm a big David Fincher fan but I have to admit that he really messed up on this on. "Zodiac", a story about the hunt for the eponymous murderer who terrorized California for years, has high production values but falls completely flat.

The movie is basically a series of loosely connected scenes that tell (part of) the story of the famous murderer and some people that try to hunt him down. There's nothing wrong with having so many plot lines in a movie but in Zodiac it's poorly done. The movie jumps around between so many characters and makes so many leaps in time that it feels very disjointed and unfocused. It's almost like watching a Discovery Channel documentary where you get to see reenactments of the most important parts from the plot.

While it's true that the acting and the production values are of much higher quality than in such a documentary, that's just about everything that can be said in "Zodiac"'s favour. The bottom line is: nothing what happens is really all that interesting. There are poorly worked out characters you don't care about, an investigation that goes nowhere, and a fairly unconvincing theory about who the Zodiac really was.

While the movie does pack up a bit towards the end (once Graysmith becomes personally involved in tracking down Zodiac there is finally a bit of suspense), it's not nearly enough to make up for a seemingly endless series of scenes that ultimately go nowhere.

In the end, I don't know what to do with "Zodiac". I can live with the fact that's it's not a standard thriller, but it doesn't do anything else very well. It's not a gripping tale with characters you care about, it's not a convincing investigation of who the Zodiac really was, and if you really want to know about the Zodiac you're much better off on Wikipedia or the Discovery Channel.

**1/2 out of ***** (the acting is good and it looks very convincing; that should count for something)

title: Uninspiring
review: The dark, grungy atmosphere that works miracles for Se7en fails to hit the target in Zodiac. There's just a tad too much unsolved mystery, an unfinished story line too many. I believe the film tries to feed the viewer too much information. The detailed facts which make the book exciting reading material distracts and takes the pace out of the movie. Perhaps the film would have benefited from a asynchronous sequence. Basically I spent most of the time waiting for something to glue me to the screen and it just didn't come. The high rating probably has more to do with Fincher's name being attached to the movie than its cinematic merits. I wonder if I was the only one begging for some lights to be turned on in this too dark flick. (5/10)

title: Boring, far too long
review:
Like most people I have been captivated by the trailers and really looking forward to this film. I've now been to see it and I can't begin to understand how it is rated so highly.

OK, the acting is good, very good in fact, but the story just doesn't hold your interest and I knew nothing about the case prior to seeing the film. The film does build up to its ending but never delivers you leave the cinema reading the white on black text saying "well if you'd said that 2 hours ago I could have saved myself these really stiff joints".

Don't bother, not even on DVD.

title: Worth Seeing
review:
I thought this movie was very well done. It was more of a psychological thriller rather than some teenage slasher movie (think Freddy Krueger or Jason part 29) where someone is getting a body part hacked off every five minutes. If that's what you're looking for this isn't the movie for you. I'm too young to remember the actual case, however, I've read a fair amount about it. The fact that this crime is still unsolved makes it all the more intriguing.

This case really affected those who were working to solve it, and it completely overtook some of their lives, which I believe, was totally intended by the Zodiac.

title: The Main Maniac: The Zodiac
review: Going into Zodiac I was somewhat aware of who the Zodiac killer was, but I knew nothing about what type of investigation was put forth. I knew that the Zodiac killer was never caught, but I didn't know the killer teased the media and police with notes and phone calls. Actually, I thought the Zodiac killer was never even close to being captured. This movie also sheds a new light on this. The movie brings you deep into the world of investigating and brings you back to the days where you were afraid to go outside, or even let your kids go to school on the bus. Led by Fincher's directing and followed by the professional acting of probably a dozen known actors, the movie's runtime of two and a half hours barely feels like it....unless, you have achey knees or no butt muscles. :) I just need to give a shout to John Carroll Lynch from The Drew Carey Show, he plays his role incredibly well, 100% believable and inspired. If you're into crime/mystery/serial killer movies, or if you're looking for some more information on the Zodiac Killer and the investigation, look no further. 8 outta 10

title: What a Masterpiece!
review:
Zodiac is a 2007 movie directed by David Fincher starring Jake Gyllenhall, Robert Downey Jr and Mark Ruffalo. This movie is a drama/thriller. The true story of the investigation of the "Zodiac Killer", a serial killer who terrified the San Francisco Bay Area, taunting police with his ciphers and letters. The case becomes an obsession for three men as their lives and careers are built and destroyed by the endless trail of clues. What an incredible movie. The cast is fantastic. Jake Gyllenhall, Robert Downey Jr and Mark Ruffalo did an amazing job, especially Jake Gyllenhall. The direction by David Fincher is stunning. The cinematography and camara work were very very good. The story is fascinating. The dialouge is great. The film is very well paced. It never feels boring. It´s very entertaining and enjoyable. The fact that the Zodiac killer was never caught is terrifying. The obession created by Robert Greysmith is somehow interesting and distrubing at the same time. Zodiac is not just an out-standing movie, but a fascinating piece of story telling. This movie also succeeds being tense and wow. What a very tense movie. Every scene with the Zodiac Killer is so very tense. David Fincher proves again why he is one of the best directors currently working. Every aspect of this movie is extraordinary. It´s ridiculous to think that Zodiac wasn´t nominated for not even one Oscar. The Oscars don´t determine what which movie is good or bad. One of the most fantastic movies I ever seen. If you ask me what a perfect movie is, I would say Zodiac. What a movie. What a masterpiece.

100/100.

title: A Realistically Real Story
review: I'll be the one to admit Zodiac is not the most fast paced or action packed movie -in fact there is rarely either of those things in it- but its sometimes very slow and repetitive nature does rewards us with the exact feeling that the people investigating the Zodiac killer experienced back in the days when they went YEARS with radio silence not knowing if they ever came close to finding him or not. Does it have a extremely satisfying and epic ending? No. But that's the beauty of this movie. It doesn't betray reality for the means of making a blockbuster. A definite must watch. You just need to keep a open mind while watching it.

title: And the case still remains unsolved
review:
Zodiac is a mystery thriller movie directed by David Fincher and stars Jack Gyllenhaal, Mark Ruffalo, Robert Downey Jr., Anthony Edwards, Chloë Sevigny, Brian Cox and John Carroll Lynch in the leads.

The movie is based on a book by Robert Graysmith played by Jack Gyllenhaal about an unsolved serial murder in late 60s and early 70s.

The best part of the movie is it's accuracy about the murder, it's depiction and creating the real locations.

The acting is good specially by Jack Gyllenhaal and Mark Ruffalo. Robert Downey Jr. could've been utilised much better.

Screenplay is slow but somewhat the same is required to take out the authenticity of the subject. David Fincher is known for murder mysteries and he again proves with this movie.

As mentioned earlier that some section of viewers can dislike the movie due to it's pace as murder mysteries are generally fast paced but slow screenplay was required.

Overall a slow but nice movie.

title: Good good
review: Nice thriller,good cast and acting. Jake Gyllenhal is by far my favourite actor.

title: David Fincher's Excellent Movie
review:
Zodiac is a brilliant descent into one of the most infamous unsolved murder cases in history. To all the people who've got their brains sunken into their skulls, this is a TRUE story, and as I've said the case is currently unsolved, meaning this is a story where the heroes DON'T get closure, WHICH might be the dumb reason why some people might be so salty why the killer is'int revealed in the end, do your homework kids.

Okay, to get that out of the way the movie itself is one the best TRUE murder crime stories ever told. The acting alone is the biggest thing that makes this move shine. The accuracy is an other big one to, if you watch the special features you could tell that David Fincher, who yet again does a great job at directing, wanted to painstakingly recreate the murder scenes as correct as possible. An other great thing about the movie is the pacing which is crazy because of the movie's length, I've seen this movie about 5 times, and it gets better for me each time, in fact Fincher asked the actors to read their lines faster than usual to make the movie not as long as it already is.

For the people who are still not listening and don't want to listen, go watch the pretty terrible "Awakening the Zodiac" movie, its shorter and it "reveals" the killer in the end.

title: Solid dramatization
review: A pretty compelling account of the Zodiac killer and ensuing investigation over decades. It's long, almost too long, but it matches just how drawn out the case was, and allows for all sorts of little details, the fleshing out of the people involved, and the eeriness of never really knowing to unfold. The names and places sometimes fly fast and furious, but the story is well told in many ways, starting with what the frustration does to the monomaniacal police and reporters looking into it. Mostly it feels like a mental thriller, but damn, that basement scene is truly scary. The circumstantial case against Arthur Leigh Allen is well laid out, and to me it was pretty surprising that he eluded more aggressive investigation and arrest, e.g. the amount of time between the testimony of Donald Cheney and the first search warrant, but of course, that's with the benefit of hindsight. Jake Gyllenhaal, Mark Ruffalo, Robert Downey Jr., and Anthony Edwards all do well here, and this a very solid dramatization.

title: A must watch!!
review: Movie was long but it was gripping through out.People who want to watch a better crime thriller than the most , this movie is for you. Jake Gyllenhaal was the stand out.

title: Best Movie By David Fincher So Far.
review:
This movie of Fincher is where you'll find tricks and gimmicks really low and it may makes this movie uninteresting to mass audience but it is just your poor taste which is stopping you from liking this great movie by Fincher. This indeed is one of those underrated gems we always forget to appreciate. The idea was here to showcase those hectic schedule of all workers on this still unknown killer's case in the thrilling way possible. This movie is basically Drama and Thriller mixed in one bag, let me tell you this isn't any cookie cutter idea and this is really hard to handle well enough. D. Fincher didn't perfectly nailed it, it is indeed true but still what he did is way better than what guys like Nolan do most of the time. The soundtrack, cinematography, production design and almost everything else is beautifully handled. I don't recall any flaw in those aspects. The only flaws are into the drama and some cheap thriller tricks of this movie, the cheap thriller tricks were really cartoonish and exaggerated, those were as if they wanted to just create a fabricated childish thrill for us, which was really disappointing, and unnecessary overall. It doesn't ruins the overall experience of the movie tbh. And hence, the movie all in all is pleasant gift to us all with no personal satisfaction.

(IN-DEPTH)

The story of this movie is about reporters and investigators' journey of finding an unknown killer from late 1960s to early 1970s. The story is pretty simple and neat, it is highly based on the true events of life. This movie's main purpose was to show you the drama between those workers who were searching for this mysterious murderer. The personal issues, the pride and pretentious acts... everything here is available for us to witness in this movie. The story is nicely handled without any doubt but sometime comes some part which are really simple but not well executed scenes. In another word, there were some really formulaic scenes which could have been improved in this movie. They can be shown with some originality but here they were shown as they are normally always done in movies. There wasn't any charm of their own in them. This kinda makes this movie sometimes a bit stale.

The Direction of this movie is flawless and beautifully done. It is Fincher! Of course, this part was gonna be on rocks! The scenes are well directed, camera work is a pure gem, the idea of showcasing this drama in such shady thriller way is highly the effort of director which makes it shine. The shootouts, choreography, dialogue delivery, and everything else is nicely handled by the director here. The direction is obviously not some Nolan type with majority of childish executions and plot-holes/errors/bugs outta nowhere. It is profound in its own kind.

Screenplay is really good but still yet it is the main issue of this movie. The dialogues are really "already used ones" stick here, and most of the scenes are highly predictable and sometimes some are goofy too. The whole famous basement scene which I had heard a lot about, was really an exaggerated thriller scene done in really childish way tbh. It was emitting from the start that it will be some common horror scene to thrill us. It was really looking cartoonish to even exist in this mature drama. The whole build up of it was really disappointing. Now, many will claim it to be showcasing Jake Gyllenhal character's fear or anything, and look I get it but the usage is a bit really over the top in this moment. The way they talk and all was really childishly handled. This scene was really not needed as well in any manner. And also, this scene yet had no originality in any manner as well. Many more scenes there were like this. The lack of anything new and original was something this movie was suffering from. It doesn't matters if you are doing something normal or simple or otherwise, the main deal is to modify it or do something to create it in such way, so you can call it your own work. It is something many directors need to learn.

Actors have done justice to their characters. Without any doubt they have act well enough. Characters are really good and interesting to watch but still they aren't something which we will remember after this movie. The issue is on the writing which I have already talked about. There is a lot of typical and stale vibe in those characters in many times. It could have been improved and we all would have seen something new.

The soundtrack is really nicely handled here with songs and music fitting every situation you are roamimg in this movie. The cinematopgraphy is profound too, it is the heart of this movie. If you want to enjoy a visual ride of San Francisco, this movie is among the best rides. The whole design and I mean every single one be it set design, costume design or any one, is phenomenal, and is worth your time and even dime.

Now, the best and most subtle, mature and profound thing apart from Drama into Thriller genre is the universe of this movie. The whole world build in this movie is so depth and well made, you'll remember it no matter what. This is not something you'll see in Nolan movies which is a blank world with beautiful practical effects and set design and all. Nolan and many gimmicky directors or even highly thriller directors always lack this aspect. They just build up a set design and then, they are done. David Fincher just showed once again, why the building up and making it more natural and more detail is more better than just a blank universe. The universe of this movie is filled with small, small details and small characters which are portrayed accurately. The whole universe is really a big delight in this movie cuz it is well established and well maintained.

All in all, this movie is the best Fincher movie tbh, this movie carries Fincher's big weapon of thriller with intense drama. This movie is providing the trademark of D. Fincher but the good news is that it is not it. It do have some issues which I have already stated but it is still great enough to have a time which you'll enjoy or not but you'll remember for sure.

ZODIAC 8/10

title: Nearly perfect
review: I have watched this film no less than 5 times and I find it fascinating with every viewing. It's early in Savid Finchers career but his brilliance is present throughout. The story is engaging and the cast is just about perfect with fabulous performances from Gyllenhahl and Ruffalo - not to mention the comeback of RDJ post rehab and pre Marvel movie superstardom. The plot peels the layers of the pursuit of the Zodiak serial killer away like an onion. We dive in with them as they follow the clues and leads for more than a decade. Highly recommended.

title: The definition of a thriller
review: This movie is well written, well acted, and the attention to detail is incredible. A superb film that will leave you shaken and maybe a little sick to your stomach.

title: One of the best Thriller's ever made
review:
Immensely thrilling, engaging, and by far entertaining, Zodiac makes use of its 2 and a half hour runtime in the best way possible. The film is incredibly gripping, with a sense of direction that makes the audience feel like its not only on edge but that these things are truly happening right in front of you. The script may seem a bit choppy at times, but mainly, it's only because there is simply so much information in the lifetime of a case like this. The performances are brilliant, with Jake Gyllenhaal being the best of the leads, but with the other two leads (Downey and Ruffalo), also making more than a mark. John Carroll Lynch also provides for a good supporting performance, as well as pretty much the denture supporting cast. In the end, David Fincher's Zodiac is not only a one of a kind thriller masterpiece, it's also a film that is bound to stand the test of time.
My Rating: 10/10

title: Just give it a try you will not regret it.
review: I think tried to show it from the robert's perspective so we did get to know about killers perspective that's why some people may find it slow and boring but this what we know about the zodiac u can't just spice it up.

title: my notes
review: You know it's a great movie when it's 2 hours and 42 minutes of mostly talking and you're not bored at any point in the movie. to say i was invested is an understatement. great cast, superb directing, and a very big story. After seeing this again, I realize that David Fincher is my second favorite director after Christopher Nolan (2 viewings)

title: THE MOST DANGEROUS GAME
review:
This is a film about the infamous Zodiac killer. It starts in 1969 and spans over 2 1/2 hours to 1991, The film centers on Robert Graysmith (Jake Gyllenhall) a cartoonist for the San Francisco Chronicle who is obsessed with solving the crime which involves a fellow reporter and numerous police officials. He accuses a number of suspects, each of which lacks for a hand writing or fingerprint match.

The film shows a few murders, but is hardly gruesome. The exciting scenes consisted of opening letters from the zodiac and Jake scratching his head. It was a rather boring police drama.

There is a cutout of "Dirty Harry" in one of the scenes, a man who got his "zodiac style" killer.

Interesting as a history, but not as a crime drama.

Parental Guide: no f-bombs, sex, or nudity.

title: WOW- just wow!
review: I'm 12 years late and I've just watched zodiac this evening and I'm utterly speechless. Where should I start? The acting? Well jake gyllenhaal KILLED IT and RDJ and mark also did a wonderful job. I wish I watched this masterpiece sooner but better late than never! Definitely gonna watch this 5 times more

title: A roller coaster of optimistic intrigue and pessimistic exhaustion.
review: The greatness of Zodiac is in it's monotony. The detectives' and journalists' wide-eyes slowly begin to sag as they seem to get further away from catching the infamous killer. We descend into madness with these characters; their obsession becomes ours, leaving us as flustered and frustration as they are. And because of its length and scope, you really experience the passing of every increasingly defeating year.

title: going through ultimate sensations
review: One of the best thrillers not only of 21st century but the entire filmline for sure . the suspense takes everyone in a bizarre nail chewing posture and if you are looking for the utmost thriller with such a great suspense , this is a must watch movie . LOOKING FOR SUSPENSE+THRILLER , YOU ARE AT THE RIGHT PLACE.

title: Zodiac, much like its cryptic codes, keeps you coming back for more.
review: I remember watching this for the first time a few years ago thinking it was an unmemorable slow drag. Revisiting this was an excellent idea. Why? Well my opinion has changed. Based on the Zodiac killings of California back in the late 60s, a journalist, cartoonist and homicide detective are entangled in a seemingly uncrackable case. With each murder, the killer leaves a cryptic message behind for the San Fransisco Chronicle to publish. On the surface this is a dark crime mystery, however underneath the authentic 60s production value is a story about obsession. How it can manifest and manipulate your mind, turning yourself into a determined individual but at the cost of losing your job, friends and family. These three employees became so fixated on publicising The Zodiac and attempting to uncover the suspect behind the codes, that actually it became a detriment to them. The lavish direction from renowned director David Fincher illustrated the case as if we, the viewers, were apart of the team. The evidence was meticulously presented so that we could attempt to work it out ourselves, which is where the thrills and emotional investment come into play. The slow paced story allowed the characters to truly interact with each other and become fully developed, thus conveying the concept of obsession enigmatically. Gyllenhaal, Ruffalo and Downey Jr had a fair share of screen time where each of the three acts focussed on one character in greater detail, whilst still progressing the case in a linear narrative. Not a easy task, but Fincher made it look effortless. The basement scene towards the end was heart pounding, Fincher did not need to conform to typical thriller traits to create suspense. The constant time hopping between scenes prevented a narrative flow, it felt disconnected occasionally. One day later, one year later, seven and a half years later...we get it, the case went on for a long time. Despite being a slow burner, this mystery will keep you glued to the screen. Taut, tense and thrilling!

title: My personal favorite David Fincher movie
review:
Described as 'boring' and 'without a satisfying ending' by a friend of mine, 'Zodiac' is a brooding and bleak look into detective procedure. It's a bit like 'The Killing' in that way.

'Zodiac' is a faithful retelling of an actual murder case, based on a book written on the case by a reporter who devoted much of his life to studying it. The movie presents the mass of clues, the plentiful evidence and the various people working on the case in a clear and easy-to-follow manner, a daunting task which deserves credit. The case invites you to dive deeper and deeper into the evidence and make up your theories, and it can get you really obsessed, which is what happens to the characters in the movie.

Like the tagline says, 'there's more than one way to lose your life to a killer'. The characters are rarely in any actual danger - it's not an action movie. There's not any gunfights or car chases here. The danger is in getting your priorities in the wrong order, in trying to solve the unsolvable, following leads that take you nowhere, devoting you time to things that take you away from real life.

David Fincher is one of the best directors working today. In 2007 he hadn't yet partnered up with Trent Reznor and Atticus Ross on the score department but 'Zodiac' still has that familiar Fincher thriller mood. Fincher soaks every scene in comfortable earth tones, making the movie very pleasant on the eyes, and sometimes there's good 60's pop music to listen to.

Definitely my personal favorite David Fincher movie (though I haven't seen 'The Girl With The Dragon Tattoo' yet).

title: Thriller at its best
review: David fincher,a renowned master of thriller genre has come up with a true story based upon the investigation of a series of murders which is still unsolved in north California.. The movie takes time to set up and once it sets up it take you into the investigation..Cast is perfect esp Jake.. The movie is creepy at the end..

title: Just plain dull
review:
It's eternally fascinating to see what folks will do for dollars. Right from the start, the movie is laughable and ridiculous schlock.

In The Box a financially struggling family in 1976 are given a weird box and told they have 24 hours to decide if they will press the button on the box that will result in them getting 1 million dollars and the death of somebody completely unknown to them.

The Box takes a premise, muddles it up and makes it completely ridiculous. The movie tries to tackle the big themes of human nature and our place in the universe but it never delivers. The actors are fine, but the weak plot is blotted by an unbearably slow pace

This creepy thriller movie too is way too confusing for kids and just plain horrible for adults. Still, most kids won't want to bother figuring out the movie's dark themes and plot, so do yourself a favor, think twice about giving into curiosity and leave The Box's button untouched it's so bad, it's funny.

title: A great crime puzzle...and one of Fincher's best films
review: Director David Fincher meticulously mounts this impeccably cast true-life crime-thriller concerning a serial killer self-nicknamed "The Zodiac" who terrorized Northern California from the late-1960s to the mid-1970s...and was never apprehended. Jake Gyllenhaal is solid portraying Robert Graysmith, a divorced dad with two kids working at the San Francisco Chronicle; employed as the paper's resident cartoonist, Graysmith became completely absorbed by the newspaper's reporting of (and the police department's concurrent investigation into) a series of grisly murders happening in and around the Bay Area. The film, based on Graysmith's non-fiction book, is intense and unsettling, though it does pack reams of detail and criminal minutiae into its running time--most of which dead-ends or winds up discarded. Excellent performances from Mark Ruffalo and Anthony Edwards as the two principle police inspectors on the case, also John Carroll Lynch as a factory worker and potential suspect. Not for every taste; however, as a portrait of hard-working people obsessed with solving a baffling case that dragged on for decades, quite riveting. *** from ****

title: Take a good story and tell it well, and you end up with a good movie
review:
David Fincher is so damn inconsistent.

It is astounding that the man who directed some of the biggest abortions in Hollywood history:

  • Alien III


  • the vile and laughable remake of The Girl with the Dragon Tattoo


  • The Curious Case of Benjamin Button


...

was responsible for this masterpiece!

It is, however, believable of the man who directed Fight Club, and helped produce a good chunk of House Of Cards and The Hire. I'm really looking forward to Gone Girl - I hope it's one of his 'A' game movies and not one of his 'B' game ones.

Zodiac has a great cast:

Robert Downey Jnr plays the same character he always plays - but we love him for it, he's a star not an actor. Mark Ruffalo is his classic Angryman, but it suits his cop role perfectly. But Jake G - the man delivers yet again, playing the autistic cartoonist lead perfectly.

As I say in the subject, it just goes to show: take a good book or any good story, and then just try to tell it as well as you can (good direction upon a good cast), and lo and behold you end up with a good movie.

And truth always trumps fiction!

-
